get_all_autotest_resultsdir(tag)[source]¶

Return list of all test found inside autoval_<timestamp>. The function searches for the tests which has results sub directory. For example, below is the output on the server with multiple autotest executed.

find /var/facebook/logs/havoc/results/autoval_2018-03-26_10-33-18 -name results results:- /var/facebook/logs/havoc/results/autoval_2018-03-26_10-33-18/rootfs/results /var/facebook/logs/havoc/results/autoval_2018-03-26_10-33-18/stressapp/results

shutdown()[source]¶

This command will just shutdown the system using ‘init 0’ command and the system is not brought back up This is mainly used in the time of bios flashing to do a graceful shutdown to avoid Tboot issue This supports only OpenBMC systems currently

get_full_sensor_data()[source]¶
get_scelnx_tool_path()[source]¶
get_sel_entries()[source]¶

Returns a list, where each element is a single entry of the SEL parsed into a dictionary (so it’s a list of dictionaries). SEL info from the verbose and non-verbose outputs are combined together to give comprehensive records. The SEL entries are stored in order in the list, making it easy to iterate through desired entries from the SEL.

To access the value of an attribute in a SEL record from the list use:

sel_entry_list[zero_indexed_line_number][attribute_name]

NOTE: Attribute_name must match the output from ‘sel elist -v’ EXACTLY (case sensitive, spaces, etc). –OR– Match one of these attributes which come from the non-verbose output: ‘Decoded Sensor Data’ ‘Reading’

NOTE: OEM entries are in this list as well. The attributes reported by OEM entries are different then non-OEM entries. Therefore, you must check that the attribute you want exists within each entry.

EXAMPLE: Getting the record type for the last line in the SEL: rec_type = sel_entry_list[-1][‘Record Type’]

EXAMPLE: Getting the record type of the last 5 lines in the SEL: for entry in sel_entry_list[-5:]:

x = entry[‘Record Type’]

get_sel_log_filter()[source]¶
get_verbose_sensor_data()[source]¶

Returns a dictionary of dictionaries containing the data from ‘ipmitool sensor -v’. To access elements in the dictionary use:

dictionary[<sensor_ID/name)][attribute_name]

NOTE: The sensor_ID/name and attribute_name must match the output from ‘sensor -v’ EXACTLY (case sensitive, spaces, etc).

EXAMPLE: Accessing a sensor’s upper critial field: upp_crit = dictionary[‘P1 DIMM VR1 PIN (0x16)’][‘Upper Critical’]

sensor_data()[source]¶
set_boot_order(first, second, third, fourth, fifth, UEFI=True)[source]¶

To set the boot order, you MUST specify all 5 devices to boot from, in the desired order. Note that when specifying to boot from the network, you should choose either IPv4 first OR IPv6 first, not both. If you violate either of these rules, the boot order may not end up being what you wanted (but the ipmi command will still work)!

set_dual_bios_auto_recovery(enable)[source]¶
set_sel_log_filter(critical_only)[source]¶

If critical_only is True, the BMC will only log critical events. If False, the BMC will log critical, information, and warning events.

ast_alternate_boot_source()[source]¶

Configures wdt2 to enable alternate boot source feature and triggers it 1. This will force the bmc to reboot 2. Use SPI1 as the primary boot instead of SPI0 This is a potential workaround to verified boot (Since for vboot we boot from SPI0 and verify SPI1. If someone fools the chip into booting from SPI1 directly, they can easily flash whatever they want on SPI1 and then trigger this).

bic_util_reset_boot_order()[source]¶

bmc_health_check(last_reboot=None)[source]¶

This method is to check if all the required daemons like healthd, fscd, sensord are running and started atleast2 mins ago. This check for services if they started 2 mins ago is to makesure the daemons have started and collected the required information atleast one time and out havoc tests doesnt fails sensord non-reporting errors

fru_list(slot_id=None)[source]¶
fw_update_bic(bmc_binary_file_path)[source]¶
fw_update_bicbl(bmc_binary_file_path)[source]¶
fw_update_bios(bmc_binary_file_path)[source]¶

This method is used to update the bios firmware using OOB(Out Of Band) method.

It checks if the file contains the firmware verion’s binary file, else copies the binary file from source location to the destination location. Later, performs the firmware update using the binary file after the power cycle and at the end health of the firmware is checked.

Paramaters:
bmc_binary_file_path = Binary file path on the destination location

of the BMC

Example

bmc_binary_file_path =

“/tmp/havoc_fw_test_<timestamp>/havoc_bios/F08_3A14.bin”

sensor_data()[source]¶

Gets sensor data for all the HW components that are stored in BMC returns dict of dictionaries

validate_vboot_util(filter_errors=None)[source]¶

Gets the BMC info for the OOB and gets vboot status creates a list from the value-status converts it to list of integers validates if number of zeros = 2 in the list If filter_errors is passed, then number of zeros = 2 If number of zeros = 2, vboot is validated, else it raises an exception

vboot_util()[source]¶
